issue.title: CMake Error - C++14 support for the library

content.raw:
Could you let us know which version of Ubuntu you're using (e.g. 14.04, 16.04, etc)? ~~I'm assuming you're using Ubuntu if the compiler is GCC. Also, you could you let us know what version of `gcc` and `g++` you're using? If this error is correct, then it sounds like you're using an old version of `g++` that doesn't support C++14.~~ Never mind, I just realized the GCC version is mentioned as 4.9.4 in the error message. Let me check what features that offers.

A temporary workaround that may help you get Gazebo working quickly would be to switch the `ign-math` branch to `ign-math3`. In your `ign-math` source directory, run the bash command:

`$ hg up ign-math3`

After that, continue with the build instructions as detailed in the tutorial. If that doesn't work, then you might be using a version of Ubuntu which is older than what the current Gazebo supports, and you might need to use an older version of Gazebo.
content.html:
Could you let us know which version of Ubuntu you're using (e.g. 14.04, 16.04, etc)? I'm assuming you're using Ubuntu if the compiler is GCC. Also, you could you let us know what version of gcc and g++ you're using? If this error is correct, then it sounds like you're using an old version of g++ that doesn't support C++14. Never mind, I just realized the GCC version is mentioned as 4.9.4 in the error message. Let me check what features that offers.

A temporary workaround that may help you get Gazebo working quickly would be to switch the ign-math branch to ign-math3. In your ign-math source directory, run the bash command:

$ hg up ign-math3

After that, continue with the build instructions as detailed in the tutorial. If that doesn't work, then you might be using a version of Ubuntu which is older than what the current Gazebo supports, and you might need to use an older version of Gazebo.

issue.title: CMake Error - C++14 support for the library

content.raw: Indeed, [variable templates are not available until gcc-5](https://gcc.gnu.org/projects/cxx-status.html#cxx14). The minimum version of Ubuntu that is supported by the latest version of Gazebo is Xenial (16.04) which offers `gcc-5`. If you're using Ubuntu 16.04, try to `apt-get install` `gcc-5` and `g++-5`. If you're using an older version of Ubuntu, you might need to build an older version of Gazebo from source.
content.html: Indeed, variable templates are not available until gcc-5. The minimum version of Ubuntu that is supported by the latest version of Gazebo is Xenial (16.04) which offers gcc-5. If you're using Ubuntu 16.04, try to apt-get install gcc-5 and g++-5. If you're using an older version of Ubuntu, you might need to build an older version of Gazebo from source.

issue.title: CMake Error - C++14 support for the library

content.raw:
I am working with Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS. I just tried to update gcc but I already have the latest version (5.4.1)

**Update ign-math to branch ign-math3** fixed the error !

Thank you for your quick answer, I can go further in the installation now
content.html:

Update ign-math to branch ign-math3 fixed the error !

issue.title: CMake Error - C++14 support for the library

content.raw:
The CMake error that you posted seems to indicate that it was attempting to compile with `4.9.4` which would be consistent with the problem that it's reporting (variable template feature not being available). You might want to check which version of gcc your computer is set up to use. You could perhaps uninstall `4.9.4` to force your computer to use `5.4.1`. If you don't actually have `4.9.4` installed at all, then something very strange must have happened with cmake.

I'm going to mark this issue as resolved. If you can determine for certain that the cmake error is occurring while it's trying to build with gcc version 5+, then we can reopen it.
content.html:
The CMake error that you posted seems to indicate that it was attempting to compile with 4.9.4 which would be consistent with the problem that it's reporting (variable template feature not being available). You might want to check which version of gcc your computer is set up to use. You could perhaps uninstall 4.9.4 to force your computer to use 5.4.1. If you don't actually have 4.9.4 installed at all, then something very strange must have happened with cmake.

I'm going to mark this issue as resolved. If you can determine for certain that the cmake error is occurring while it's trying to build with gcc version 5+, then we can reopen it.
